title: 109_hr4753
content:
The "Gift of Life Congressional Medal Act of 2006" authorizes the creation of a bronze medal by the Secretary of the Treasury to honor organ donors and their families. The "Gift of Life Congressional Medal Act of 2006" allows organ donors and their families to receive a medal through a documentation process overseen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The individual or family must undergo an independent investigation to determine eligibility for the medal described in section 2. SEC. 4. PRESENTATION. The Secretary of the Treasury delivers medals to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, who then directs the OPTN contractor to present the medals to eligible recipients, with a limitation of one medal per family member. The OPTN contractor may present an additional medal to each organ donor or their family if more than one family member is an organ donor. The Secretary of Health and Human Services or the OPTN contractor can provide duplicate medals to recipients under certain regulations. The price of a duplicate medal must cover the cost. The medals issued under this Act are considered national medals. Procurement regulations do not apply to goods or services needed for this Act. Solicitation of donations is allowed. The Secretary of the Treasury may collect funds to offset medal issuance costs through an agreement with the OPTN contractor. All funds received by the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network must be promptly paid to the Treasury, with a limitation of 5% for administrative costs. Amounts received by the Treasury are allocated to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury collects funds to cover medal issuance costs through an agreement with the OPTN contractor. Funds received are deposited in the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. A one-time amount of up to $55,000 is provided to the contractor for start-up costs, to be repaid within 3 years. The Secretary ensures no net cost to the Government for medal issuance. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS.

    The term "organ" refers to human kidneys, liver, heart, lung, pancreas, and other specified organs, excluding corneas and eyes. The "Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network" is established under the Public Health Service Act.

SEC. 10. SUNSET PROVISION.

    This Act is effective for a 2-year period from the date of enactment.
